titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Heard Mr: Lowrie at the Treasury-Office— His exposition was of a chapter in Galatians, relating to the controversy between the Apostles Peter and Paul, concerning the obligations of the Mosaic Law, subsequent to the Christian dispensation; a subject upon which my curiosity has lately been much excited— Mr: Lowrie was very severe upon the conduct of Peter, on this occasion; which he censured perhaps too harshly.— Mr: and Mrs: Boyd, and Mr: Bell a nephew of Mr: Hellen, just from the Mediterranean, dined with us— Mrs: Mason, and Mr: Sheldon were here in the Evening.

2. This being the first Monday in December, is the day fixed by the Constitution for the meeting of Congress, and a quorum of both houses accordingly assembled— The Vice-President not being here, Mr: Samuel Smith, of Maryland, was chosen President of the Senate pro Tempore, and after passing the usual Resolutions at the Commencement of a Session the Senate adjourned— I then went in to the House of Representatives, and saw their organization— Mr: Macon was chosen Speaker, and the other Officers of the former house were re-elected. The house adjourned between 2 and 3 O’Clock.— The new Members who appeared in Senate, were James Fenner of Rhode-Island, Nicholas Gilman of New-Hampshire, Aaron Kitchell of New-Jersey, and Daniel Smith of Tennessee. This Evening I resumed the study of Greek; for which however I shall have very little time, this winter.

3. At twelve O’Clock this day, the President’s Message was delivered by his Secretary Mr: Coles— It was read and ordered to be printed— No other business was done, and the Senate adjourned very early— I went in to the House of Representatives, where there was nothing important. They also soon adjourned.— Dined with all the family at Mr: Boyd’s; and spent the Evening there.

4. The only business done in Senate, was making choice of a chaplain.— Dr: Gantt.— Adjourned before one O’Clock. I went in to the House, where I got Mr: Quincy to present the petition of Captain Richard Beale, which was referr’d to the Committee of Claims— I paid a visit to Mr: Tayloe. Met there Mr: and Mrs: Merry— I took from the Library Ward’s Inquiry into the History of the Law of Nations in Europe, before the time of Grotius— Read the preface and first two Chapters.—in the first, on the Question “What the Law of Nations is.”—after discussing the various opinions of former writers, he concludes that it is composed of the Law of Nature, & of certain positive Customs.— In the second; on the obligation of natural Law, he considers the question as to its universality, and pronounces against it; because he finds no one principle prescribed by it, but has been frequently disregarded and counteracted by many whole Nations, civilized, and uncivilized.

5. A bill for an additional appropriation to make up a deficiency in the naval department pass’d to the third reading; and would have pass’d the Senate as it did the house, without a question why the deficiency happened, but for a motion of Mr: Tracy to call on the Secretary of the Navy for that information; which pass’d— Senate adjourned about 1. O’Clock— I called on the Secretary of the Treasury Mr: Gallatin, and at last found him at his Office— He gave me the papers of Mr: Boylston which I wanted, and some information relative to his claim— At home I read several chapters further in Ward.

6. The information requested was this day received from the Secretary of the Navy, and the bill pass’d. Senate adjourned soon after 12. and about a half an hour after, Mr: Coles the President’s Secretary, came with a confidential Message to both Houses— Some of the Members of the Senate proposed to resume the Session by unanimous consent, and direct the Secretary not to enter the adjournment; but this would have been a dangerous precedent and was not agreed to— The adjournment was untill Monday— Mrs: Adams spent the afternoon and Evening with Mrs: Mason of Georgetown— I continued reading the first Volume of Ward.

7. At 11. this morning, I attended the Committee on the appropriation of monies to lay out roads from the Atlantic to the Ohio. The other members are Messrs: Tracy, Anderson, Worthington and Wright— We sat in Committee nearly three hours; and came to some Resolutions on which Mr: Tracy is to found a report, and a bill— When ready, he is to call the Committee together again— Mr: Tracy shews in all his proceedings public conduct, great experience, and a thorough familiarity with the order and course of legislative proceedings— His manner is peculiarly accommodating and conciliatory; his command of temper exemplary.— In public affairs it appears to me there is no quality more useful and important than good-humour, because it operates continually to soften the asperities which are continually rising in the collisions of adverse interests and opinions; and this quality Tracy possesses in a high degree— Mr: Worthington is a man of plausible, insinuating address, and of indefatigable activity, in the pursuit of his purposes. He has seen something of the world, and without much education of any other sort has acquired a sort of polish in his manners, and a kind of worldly wisdom, which may perhaps more properly be called cunning.— Mr: Wright with a capacity below the ordinary level, a violent temper, at once obstinate and unsteady, and a perpetually bustling disposition is one of the least respected, though not the least effective members of the Senate.— He takes a part in every debate— Speaks upon every subject; and very seldom without exposing himself by some absurdity in argument, or some confusion of learning— He told us this day, very seriously, that Praisegod Barebones was a Massachusetts name.— Mr: Anderson is a lawyer of good understanding, and good education— Acquainted with good principles, but often warped by the pressure of popular opinions.— Seldom daring to act according to his own ideas, and willing to see the burden of responsibility fall any where but upon himself— I dined this day at Lieutenant Thompson’s— Mr: Eaton, and several of our naval Officers were there; with some other Gentlemen— Mr: Hellen went to Alexandria; and returned before Night— Coming home from the Capitol I met General Miranda who gave me a letter from Coll: Smith; and promised to call and see me— I had also a letter from Mr: Ewing.

8. Captain Landais, an old acquaintance whom I had not seen for upwards of twenty years, called upon me this morning, and sat with me a couple of hours, which prevented me from going out— I had recognized him
him two days since, walking in one of the Entrance rooms at the Capitol, and accosted him by name.— He did not then immediately know me; but on my explaining to him who I was, remembered me— My acquaintance with him was in the Spring and Summer of the year 1779. at Brest, Nantes and l’Orient—on board the frigate Alliance which he then commanded; and on board of which I was to have returned with my father to this Country— But the destination of the Alliance was changed, and we came home in the french frigate la Sensible— Captain Landais this morning gave me a history of his life since that time, which has been various and full of adventure— He is now here with a claim upon Congress, for his share of certain prizes captured by him during the American War— After he was gone, I returned Mr: Merry’s visit; but he was not at home— I walked into Georgetown, and returned home to dinner— In the Evening Mr: Petry, General Tureau’s Secretary of Legation was here.

9. Attended in Senate, where a voluminous communication of documents received from the President was read. After which we adjourned; between 1. and 2— I dined at the President’s, in company with the Tunisian Ambassador, and his two Secretaries— By the invitation, dinner was to have been on the table precisely at Sun-Set.— It being in the midst of the Ramadan, during which the Turks fast, while the Sun is above the horizon— He did not arrive untill half an hour after Sun-set, and immediately after greeting the President and the company, proposed to retire, and smoke his pipe— The President requested him to smoke it there, which he accordingly did; taking at the same time snuff deeply scented with Otto of Roses— We then went to dinner, where he freely partook of the dishes on the table, without enquiring into the Cookery— Mrs: Randolph the President’s daughter and her daughter were the only Ladies there, and immediately after they returned to the drawing-Room after dinner, the Ambassador followed them, to smoke his pipe again— His Secretaries remained after him just long enough to take each a glass of Wine, which they did not venture to do in his presence.— His dress differed from that of the Turks. He wears his beard long— His Secretaries only wear whiskers.— His manners are courteous, but we were all unable to converse with him; but through the medium of an interpreter. The company was Mr: S. Smith President of the Senate, Dr: Logan, and Dr: Mitchill— Mr: John Randolph, Mr: Nicholson, and Mr: Dawson of the House of Representatives, and the President’s two Sons in Law, Mr: T. M. Randolph and Mr: Eppes; with Mr: Coles his Secretary, and Dr: Davis who acted as interpreter— I had some conversation at table with Mr: T. M. Randolph, who appears sensible and well-informed.— I came home at about 9. in the Evening.

10. In Senate, a second Communication of numerous documents from the President was read and occupied two hours of the time; after which we immediately adjourned— Mrs: Adams pass’d the Evening at her Sister Boyd’s— I wrote to Mr: James Smith; and commenced the second volume of Ward.

11. The President sent the Senate a large bundle of Treaties concluded since the last Session, with the documents attending their Negotiation— They were all read and Senate adjourned between 1 and 2 o’clock— I wrote to Mr: Boylston. Dined at Mr: Caldwell’s— Mr: Eaton—Messrs: Tracy, Dana, Simmons, two Davidson’s and Boyd—made the Company. Mr Eaton gave us an account of his expedition in Barbary; and discovered great bitterness against Mr: Lear— I came home early this Evening, and read Colman’s play, “Who wants a Guinea?[”]— Mrs: Adams at Mrs: Thompson’s.

12. I received a letter from Mr: Richard Rush, which I immediately answered— No business of any consequence was done in Senate and we adjourned very early— In the Evening I went with all the Ladies excepting Caroline, to the City Assembly. The first of the Season; which was very thinly attended— The Tunisian Ambassadors and his Officers were there.— It was about 1. in the morning when we came home.

13. There was some debate in Senate on the reference of a certain Indian Treaty to a Committee, which was finally carried— Adjourned between 1 and 2. O’Clock— The Committee on the Ohio Roads met, and Mr: Tracy read a Report, which is to be submitted together with a bill formed upon it.— I returned Mr: Petry’s visit— Spent the Evening, with Mrs: Johnson, Mrs: Adams, and Catherine, at Mr: Harrison’s in Georgetown— There was a large Company there— We came home about 11. at Night— Conversed with Dr: Thornton, Mr: G. W. Campbell; and Mr: Sheldon.

14. Mr: Nelson, a member of the House of Representatives from Massachusetts called upon me, to make enquiries respecting the bills in favour of Jonathan Titcomb— Mr: and Mrs: Cutts were also here on a visit— I returned Mr: Foster’s visit— Mrs: Merry came in while I was there— In the afternoon I took a long walk with Mrs: Adams— Weather almost at Summer heat— Read part of Ward’s second volume.

15. Attended church at George-town, where I heard Mr: M’Cormick— Though he was last year chaplain to the Senate, I had never heard him preach— His Sermon was from Luke 23.43, on the general inefficacy of death bed repentance— It contained much ingenious reasoning; and a satisfactory proof, that no inference can justly be drawn from the forgiveness bestowed in the article of death, upon the penitent malefactor at the crucifixion, to warrant others in postponing repentance and reformation to so late an hour.— We had a visit from Mr: and Mrs: Simmons, this morning, and General Miranda, and Mr: Sheldon pass’d the Evening with us.

16. The Vice-President, Mr: Clinton, this day took his Seat in Senate, and five or six Treaties were read; partially discussed and referred to select Committees— A list of nominations also was received from the President, and read. It was past 3. P.M. when we adjourned— In the Evening I read Ward.

17. A long debate was held in Senate this day, on the question whether Mr: Bradley should have leave to bring in a bill to prohibit the importation of Slaves into the United States after the 1st: of January 1808— The principal question was whether consistently with the Constitution of the United States, Congress could pass any Law upon the subject prior to that year— But some of the members thinking it inexpedient to discuss the subject at this time would have refused the leave to bring in the bill, and spoke to that purpose untill he asked for the yeas and nays on the question— Then Dr: Mitchill made a long speech to shew why he should vote for giving leave, though he had previously spoken against it— The Journal he said would be the record of his Fame, and he could not suffer it to exhibit the appearance of his voting against the reception of a bill to the principle of which he was so friendly— Mr: Wright from a similar fear to vote as he wished moved the previous question— But all would not do— The Majority decided to take the question immediately, and then to receive the bill which was read; and before the question was taken whether it should go to a second reading, Mr: Bradley moved an adjournment, which was carried.— Evening at home, reading Ward.

18. Met the Committee on Ohio Roads, at 10 this morning; and after the adjournment of the Senate, they met again; and agreed to the report and Bill, drawn up by the Chairman Mr: Tracy— The Session of Senate was short— Two of the Treaties which had been committed were reported, and Resolutions for their Ratification proposed.— Mr: Bradley moved to postpone the further consideration of his bill, to the first Monday in February— Mr: Smith of Maryland moved its postponement to the first Monday in December, which was carried by the Vice-President’s casting vote. Mr: Bradley did not take the yeas and nays at this time; but suffered Dr: Mitchill to vote without fear of seeing his fair fame blasted by the record of his real opinion.— So I suppose Bradley himself had acquiesced in this disposal of his bill, which he brought in under Instructions from his State, but for the fate of which I suppose him quite indifferent.— Captain Landais called upon me this afternoon, and left with me a copy of his memorial— In the Evening I finished reading Ward’s Treatise on the Laws of Nations— I also this day began reading again the Greek Testament.

19. The principal business done in Senate this day, was the ratification of two Indian Treaties; and Resolutions were offered for the Ratification of some others.— Mr: Bradley likewise proposed some Resolutions for opening a Land-Office in the State of Tennessee— After the Senate adjourned I paid a visit to the Vice-President— Mr: Van Cortlandt, and Mr: Verplanck were here this afternoon at tea, and to spend part of the Evening.

20. Dr: Logan asked leave to bring in a bill to suspend all commerce with St: Domingo; upon which a debate of about three hours arose; and the question was finally postponed untill Monday.— In the Evening I went with the Ladies to Mr: Tayloe’s where we found a numerous company, and Cards.

21. Attended a meeting of the Committee on the Treaty with Tripoli, where it was agreed to report it without amendment— All the family excepting Mrs: Adams and myself pass’d the Evening at Mr: Merry’s.— I began reading the second Volume of Judge Marshall’s life of Washington.

22. Heard Mr: Sayrs at Georgetown— As I was going to Church I met a number of Indian Savages coming into town on horseback, and in Carriages, making a hideous howling, and a disgusting appearance.— After coming home from Church, I pass’d the remainder of the day at home; reading the second volume of Marshall— Captain Landais called upon me this morning, and Mr: Petry was here in the Evening.

23. Attended in Senate, where the principal consideration was upon certain Indian Treaties, and nominations to Office, many of which have been postponed for further enquiry— I answered Mr: Ewing’s letter; and saw Mr: Cranch, who has just returned from Alexandria, and is now attending the Circuit Court here— In the Evening I read further in Marshall.

24. There was little business done in Senate this day; and they adjourned untill Friday the 27th:— After the adjournment I went in to the House of Representatives where I found Mr: Quincy speaking, on the point of a contested election. The House adjourned only till Thursday the 26th:— I then went home with Mr: Quincy and Mr: Cranch— Dined, and sat with them untill after dark— Then walked home; a distance of at least four miles.— I answered Mr: Dexter’s letters.

25. Christmas day— I attended Church at the Capitol where a Sermon was delivered by Dr: Gantt.— There was also an Anthem and several hymns sung, accompanied with instrumental Music— There were a number of the Indians, who are here on visits, present, of the Sac and Osage tribes. After Church I went with Eliza and Adelaide Johnson accompanied by Mr: Verplanck to visit Miss Clinton, but she was gone out— I walk’d home with the Ladies— Messrs: Tracy, Dana, and Lewis dined with us and spent the Evening— But I was so unwell with a severe head-ache, and some fever, that I was obliged to leave the Company, and retire to my chamber early— Mr: Sheldon was also here.

26. I called this morning at the Secretary of State’s Office, and had some conversation with him, and with Mr: Wagner respecting Captain Landais and his claim— Called also at the Bank— Continued reading the second Volume of Marshall— In the Evening all the family excepting Mrs: Adams and me, went to the Ball.

27. Attended in Senate, where the principal business done was the passage of a bill for making a road from Cumberland to the State of Ohio— Met a procession of Masons and a number to the Indians who are here on visits— Finished reading the second and began the third Volume of Washington’s Life— My health is again deserting me; and I must again make up my mind to renounce all assiduous application.

28. Heavy Rain the whole day, which confined me to the house— In the Evening it blew a Storm— I spent the day, in writing and reading, occupations with which I could be sure never to have a wearisome moment, but for the effect they produce upon my health— I wrote some remarks on Ward’s Law of Nations, and read further in the 3d: Volume of the Life of Washington— I also read at leisure a few lines in Homer’s Iliad

29. Went with four of the Ladies this morning to the Capitol, and heard Dr: Gantt— Of his Sermon I can scarcely remember any thing; for his matter is so indifferent and his manner so bad, that Holiness itself could not command attention to his discourses— Remainder of the day at home— In the Evening Mr: Petry, Mr: Morris & Mr: Winn were here.

30. Attended in Senate— Little business done— I spent an hour before in Committee with Mr: Anderson, and Mr: Tracy, on the bill respecting foreign Coins— We concluded to revise the whole Law, instead of the partial repeal of the second Section as the House of Representatives have past the Bill— Mr: Tracy’s Resolution to request papers relative to the Treaty with Tripoli was adopted, without debate— Adjourned soon after 12. O’Clock. After the adjournment the chiefs of several Indian tribes now here on visits came with their interpreters, and address’d their Speeches to the Vice-President, who took the chair to receive them— The Cherokees differ very little in appearance from our own people. They suffer their hair to grow and wear it powdered, and dress in all respects like ourselves—use no paint; no beads, and none of the customary indian ornaments.— But the tribes from the Missouri, Osages, Sacs, and Foxes, though partly clad in clothes furnished them by our Government, were very deeply painted, and with various colours—had beads at the nose and ears, birds feather’s, fox and squirrel skins and tails, and the other decorations usual to the Savages of
this Continent before their intercourse with Europeans— The Osages were several of them remarkably strong, and athletic men; and one of them very erect in his attitude, and firm in his gait— The rest were shabby in appearance, and awkward in their deportment— Their Speeches were nearly to the same purport, complimentary to the Vice-President, whom they address’d as their grand-father, and boasting of the distance they had come to see us— The Cherokee said he hoped we should find his Nation had far advanced in their improvements; an idea seemingly suggested to him by a comparison between his tribe, and the more genuine Savages of the rest then present; and the Osage said that after travelling so far, he hoped he should go home wiser than he came—the interpreter of the Osages spoke only French, so that a second interpreter was required to give their speeches— They used considerable gesture, but it consisted principally of pointing the finger upwards and downwards alternately.— In the Evening, all the family excepting Mrs: Adams and me were at a party at Mr: Merry’s— Mrs: Adams was severely ill with one of her violent head-aches—

31. We had a short Session again in Senate this day, and adjourned over to-morrow; having scarcely any business before us— I afterwards returned a number of visits, without finding any of the Gentlemen at home— Spent the Evening in writing and reading— Finished the third Volume of Marshall’s life of Washington.

Day— Rise between 7 and 8 in the morning; usually about Sun-rise— Read in the Greek Testament or Homer’s Iliad untill 9. Breakfast— Walk to the Capitol; and attend at the Senate-Chamber untill 2 or 3. Walk home— Dine about four— From five untill 9 in the Evening, I generally read; sometimes write about half an hour— Pass very few Evenings in Company, either abroad or at home— Sup at 9. and soon after 10 seek the repose of Night.

In Reviewing the occurrences of the year, which is now closing I find equal reason for sentiments of Gratitude to Providence for the blessings I have enjoyed in its progress, and of self reproof for the little advantage I have derived from them— The two first, and the last Month of the year were pass’d in attendance on my duty in Congress, where I have not been so profitable a servant as I might be— Not that I have positively neglected my duty; but because I have not exerted myself in its discharge with sufficient vigour and ardour— When I returned to Quincy last Spring, my intention was by an assiduous application to subjects of public concern to remove part of the ignorance which often interferes with my wishes to serve the public— I had barely commenced the execution of this design, when ill-health compell’d me to lay it aside— And before I could resume it, my appointment to the Professorship at Cambridge gave my studies necessarily a new and different direction.— From the beginning of July a large portion of my time has been devoted to the Greek Language, and to Rhetorical Writers— And these are fields which I must for years to come (if my life be spared) explore and cultivate with unabating industry, or without effect.— My health has been worse during the course of the whole year than I had long experienced, and its prospects are not flattering; but my Parents, my wife and my children have all lived, and in general been blest with health, for which Heaven be praised— My political prospects continue declining. The state of my affairs in other respects remains nearly as at the commencement of the year— In some respects improved; in others less advantageous; but on the whole more favourable and promising— The privations to which I have found it necessary to recur have been very painful as they respect my family, and in their effects, though on my own account they never had on my mind or spirits the weight of a Straw— Thus much for the past, upon which reflection can be of no use, but as it may influence the conduct of the future— Let me then resolve to devote that future to the steady pursuit of real Wisdom and Virtue; and let me pray for assistance from above that the general imperfections of humanity and my peculiar individual frailties and infirmities may be successfully overcome by the stronger and increasing powers of Justice, Temperance, Patience, and Fortitude.
